courseName: AI-2 Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning & Computer Vision

lessons.lessonTitle:
Introduction to AI

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What is the relationship between AI, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning?
A) They are completely different fields
B) AI contains ML, ML contains Deep Learning ✓
C) Deep Learning contains ML, ML contains AI
D) They are all the same thing

### Q2: Code Understanding
What limitation does this Turing test simulation demonstrate?
```python
def turing_test_simulation(response_human, response_ai):
    if len(response_ai) > 0 and "I am" not in response_ai:
        return "AI might pass this round"
    return "Human response detected"
```
A) It's too complex for simple testing
B) It uses simple keyword matching rather than understanding context ✓
C) It doesn't work with any responses
D) It always identifies AI correctly

### Q3: Problem-Solving
What AI approach would you recommend for reducing human errors in quality control?
A) Expert systems only
B) Computer vision for visual inspection ✓
C) Natural language processing
D) Recommendation systems

### Q4: Application
How is AI currently being used in healthcare?
A) Only for entertainment
B) Diagnosis assistance and medical imaging analysis ✓
C) Only for billing systems
D) Only for appointment scheduling

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
What is the most important ethical concern about AI to address?
A) AI is too expensive
B) Bias, privacy, and job displacement impacts ✓
C) AI is too slow
D) AI uses too much electricity

---

lessons.lessonTitle:
Machine Learning

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What is the difference between traditional programming and machine learning?
A) No difference
B) Traditional uses explicit rules, ML learns patterns from data ✓
C) ML is always faster than traditional programming
D) Traditional programming is newer than ML

### Q2: Code Understanding
Why is the train-test split important in this code?
```python
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.2)
```
A) To make the code run faster
B) To prevent overfitting and allow unbiased performance evaluation ✓
C) To use less memory
D) To make the data look better

### Q3: Problem-Solving
You have 10,000 customer emails labeled as "spam" or "not spam". Which type of ML would you use?
A) Unsupervised learning
B) Supervised learning (classification) ✓
C) Reinforcement learning
D) Deep learning only

### Q4: Application
How does Netflix's recommendation system work?
A) Random suggestions
B) Analyzes viewing patterns and user preferences through collaborative filtering ✓
C) Only shows popular movies
D) Uses only genre information

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
How can biased training data lead to unfair outcomes?
A) It can't, all data is fair
B) Historical bias in data can perpetuate discrimination in AI decisions ✓
C) Biased data makes AI faster
D) Biased data only affects accuracy

---

lessons.lessonTitle:
Supervised & Unsupervised Learning

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What is the key difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?
A) Supervised is faster than unsupervised
B) Supervised uses labeled data, unsupervised finds patterns without labels ✓
C) Unsupervised is more accurate than supervised
D) They use different programming languages

### Q2: Code Understanding
What type of learning is this K-means clustering code?
```python
kmeans = KMeans(n_clusters=2)
clusters = kmeans.fit_predict(customer_data)
```
A) Supervised learning
B) Unsupervised learning ✓
C) Reinforcement learning
D) Deep learning

### Q3: Problem-Solving
A retail company wants to understand customer segments without existing labels. Which approach should they use?
A) Supervised learning
B) Unsupervised learning with clustering algorithms ✓
C) Reinforcement learning
D) Traditional programming

### Q4: Application
How might Spotify use supervised vs unsupervised learning?
A) Only supervised for everything
B) Supervised for user preferences, unsupervised for playlist themes ✓
C) Only unsupervised for everything
D) Neither type of learning

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
How can unsupervised learning lead to unexpected discoveries?
A) It can't discover anything new
B) It can reveal hidden patterns like new disease subtypes or fraud patterns ✓
C) It only confirms what we already know
D) It's too simple to discover anything

---

lessons.lessonTitle:
Machine Learning Process

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What are the six steps of the machine learning process?
A) Problem definition, data collection, preprocessing, model selection, training, evaluation ✓
B) Collect, clean, sort, analyze, report, present
C) Start, load, process, calculate, finish, save
D) Input, output, calculate, test, deploy, maintain

### Q2: Code Understanding
What ML process steps does this code represent?
```python
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X_train)
model = LinearRegression()
model.fit(X_scaled, y_train)
```
A) Only model training
B) Data preprocessing and model training ✓
C) Only data collection
D) Only evaluation

### Q3: Problem-Solving
Your model has 85% accuracy on training data but 60% on test data. What's the problem?
A) The model is perfect
B) Overfitting - the model memorized training data ✓
C) The test data is wrong
D) Not enough training time

### Q4: Application
How would a hospital apply the ML process for predicting patient readmission?
A) Skip data collection and go straight to modeling
B) Define criteria → collect EHR data → preprocess → train → evaluate → deploy ✓
C) Only use doctor opinions
D) Use only simple rules

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
Why is the ML process iterative?
A) To waste time
B) Poor performance often requires revisiting data collection or preprocessing ✓
C) To make it more complicated
D) Computers work better with repetition

---

lessons.lessonTitle:
Data Preparation

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What are four main types of data quality issues?
A) Missing values, duplicates, incorrect formatting, outliers ✓
B) Too much, too little, too fast, too slow
C) Red, green, blue, yellow data
D) Old, new, medium, fresh data

### Q2: Code Understanding
What data quality issues is this code addressing?
```python
df['revenue'].fillna(df['revenue'].median(), inplace=True)
df.dropna(subset=['customer_id'], inplace=True)
df.drop_duplicates(inplace=True)
```
A) Only missing values
B) Missing values, critical missing data, and duplicates ✓
C) Only duplicates
D) Only formatting issues

### Q3: Problem-Solving
How would you clean a customer review dataset with missing ratings and duplicate reviews?
A) Delete everything
B) Impute ratings using sentiment analysis, investigate duplicates for spam ✓
C) Keep everything as is
D) Only use complete reviews

### Q4: Application
How would dirty data with bot traffic affect ML model performance?
A) No effect
B) Skewed behavior patterns and biased predictions ✓
C) Better performance
D) Faster training

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
Why does data preparation take 80% of a data scientist's time?
A) Data scientists are slow workers
B) Real data is messy and requires domain knowledge and iterations ✓
C) The tools are bad
D) It's unnecessary but traditional

---

lessons.lessonTitle:
Classification

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
When would you prioritize recall over precision?
A) When false positives are more costly
B) When false negatives are more costly (like medical diagnosis) ✓
C) When you want balanced results
D) Never prioritize one over the other

### Q2: Code Understanding
What might this decision tree learn from email features?
```python
# features = [word_count, spam_words, links]
X_train = [[150, 2, 1], [50, 8, 5]]
y_train = ['ham', 'spam']
```
A) All emails are spam
B) High spam_words + links likely indicate spam ✓
C) Word count determines everything
D) Nothing can be learned

### Q3: Problem-Solving
How would you optimize a medical diagnostic system where missing cancer (false negative) is worse than false alarms?
A) Optimize for precision
B) Optimize for recall to minimize false negatives ✓
C) Use equal weights for both
D) Ignore the cost difference

### Q4: Application
Why do social media platforms still need human moderators alongside AI?
A) AI is always wrong
B) AI struggles with context, sarcasm, and nuanced judgment ✓
C) Humans are faster than AI
D) AI is too expensive

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
When would you choose interpretability over performance?
A) Never
B) Medical diagnosis, legal decisions, regulatory compliance ✓
C) Always
D) Only for simple problems

---

questions.prompt: When would you prioritize recall over precision?

options.text: When false positives are more costly

feedback.short: Not quite! Classification can handle more than two categories.
feedback.detailed: Multiclass classification is a fundamental capability of many ML algorithms. Binary classification (two classes) is just a special case. Many real-world problems involve multiple categories, like classifying images into dozens of object types or categorizing news articles into various topics.
feedback.socraticHint: How many different categories can you think of when classifying animals, news articles, or products?

options.text: When false negatives are more costly (like medical diagnosis)

feedback.short: Not quite! Accuracy alone can be misleading, especially with imbalanced datasets.
feedback.detailed: A model that predicts "not fraud" for every transaction could have 99% accuracy if only 1% of transactions are fraudulent, but it would be useless! For imbalanced classes, metrics like precision, recall, F1-score, or ROC-AUC provide much better insight into model performance. Always consider your specific use case when choosing metrics.
feedback.socraticHint: If you have 950 non-fraud and 50 fraud cases, what accuracy would you get by always predicting "non-fraud"?

options.text: Never prioritize one over the other

lessons.lessonTitle:
Clustering

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
How does clustering differ from classification?
A) No difference
B) Clustering groups similar data without labels, classification predicts known labels ✓
C) Clustering is supervised, classification is unsupervised
D) Clustering only works with numbers

### Q2: Code Understanding
What business insights could customer spending/frequency clusters provide?
```python
# [annual_spending, frequency_of_purchase]
customers = [[2000, 12], [8000, 24], [2500, 10]]
```
A) No useful insights
B) Low/medium/high value customer segments for targeted marketing ✓
C) Only total spending matters
D) Frequency doesn't matter

### Q3: Problem-Solving
How would clustering help a streaming service with personalized recommendations?
A) It wouldn't help
B) User segmentation for recommendations and content grouping ✓
C) Only for billing purposes
D) To reduce storage costs

### Q4: Application
How could retail stores use customer behavior clustering for store layout?
A) Random product placement
B) Place complementary products together, popular items in high-traffic areas ✓
C) Alphabetical arrangement only
D) By product color

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
How do you evaluate clustering results without "correct" answers?
A) You can't evaluate clustering
B) Domain expertise, business metrics, cluster stability, stakeholder feedback ✓
C) Random selection
D) Always use the same number of clusters

---

questions.prompt: How does clustering differ from classification?

feedback.short: Not quite! Precision and recall measure different aspects of model performance.
feedback.detailed: Precision measures how many of your positive predictions were actually correct (accuracy of positive predictions), while recall measures how many actual positives you found (completeness). They often have a trade-off relationship - improving one may decrease the other. Understanding this difference is crucial for choosing the right metric for your problem.
feedback.socraticHint: Would a spam filter that catches all spam but also flags many legitimate emails be high in precision or recall?

lessons.lessonTitle:
Natural Language Processing

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What are three main challenges computers face when processing human language?
A) Speed, memory, storage
B) Ambiguity, context, cultural references ✓
C) Grammar, spelling, punctuation
D) Length, format, encoding

### Q2: Code Understanding
What is this sentiment analysis code doing and how might businesses use it?
```python
sentiment = sia.polarity_scores("This product is amazing!")
```
A) Translating text to another language
B) Analyzing customer feedback sentiment for product improvement ✓
C) Counting words in the text
D) Checking spelling errors

### Q3: Problem-Solving
How would you automatically categorize 1000+ daily support tickets by urgency and topic?
A) Manually read each one
B) Text classification with preprocessing and feature extraction ✓
C) Random assignment
D) Use only keywords

### Q4: Application
How has machine learning enhanced Google Translate quality?
A) Made it faster only
B) Neural translation, attention mechanisms, better context understanding ✓
C) Added more languages only
D) Improved graphics

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
How do NLP systems handle constantly evolving language?
A) They don't need to adapt
B) Continuous retraining, social media data, crowd-sourcing ✓
C) Only use old text
D) Ignore new language trends

---

lessons.lessonTitle:
Text Processing

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What is the difference between stemming and lemmatization?
A) No difference
B) Stemming is faster but crude, lemmatization is accurate but slower ✓
C) Stemming is always better
D) Lemmatization only works with English

### Q2: Code Understanding
What does this text preprocessing pipeline accomplish?
```python
tokens = word_tokenize(text.lower())
filtered_tokens = [word for word in tokens if word not in stop_words]
stemmed_tokens = [stemmer.stem(word) for word in filtered_tokens]
```
A) Makes text longer
B) Normalizes text, removes noise, focuses on meaningful words ✓
C) Translates to another language
D) Adds punctuation

### Q3: Problem-Solving
How would text processing improve search results for internal company documents?
A) It wouldn't help
B) Synonyms through embeddings, stemming matches variations, semantic search ✓
C) Only exact matches work
D) Search is impossible to improve

### Q4: Application
How would you modify text processing for Twitter sentiment analysis?
A) Use standard processing only
B) Preserve hashtags/mentions, handle emojis, expand abbreviations ✓
C) Remove all special characters
D) Only analyze text length

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
When might aggressive preprocessing hurt model performance?
A) Never
B) When removing negations like "not good" → "good" ✓
C) Always
D) Only with short text

---

feedback.short: Not quite! Simple word counting is just the beginning - NLP involves understanding meaning and context.
feedback.detailed: While word frequency can be useful, true NLP involves understanding syntax, semantics, context, and linguistic structure. Modern NLP uses techniques like word embeddings, transformers, and language models to capture meaning, relationships between words, and contextual nuances that simple counting misses entirely.
feedback.socraticHint: Can you determine if a review is sarcastic ("Great, another broken product!") just by counting words?

feedback.short: Not quite! Tokenization involves complex decisions about handling punctuation, contractions, and special cases.
feedback.detailed: While splitting on spaces seems simple, real tokenization must handle: contractions (don't → do + n't), punctuation (U.S.A.), hyphenated words, URLs, emojis, and language-specific rules. Different tokenizers make different choices that significantly impact downstream NLP tasks. Modern tokenizers use subword approaches for better handling of rare words.

lessons.lessonTitle:
Streamlit

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What are three advantages of using Streamlit for ML applications?
A) Faster execution, more memory, better graphics
B) Rapid prototyping, easy deployment, Python integration ✓
C) More complex features, harder to use, expensive
D) Only works with specific ML models

### Q2: Code Understanding
What interactive features does this Streamlit app provide?
```python
uploaded_file = st.file_uploader("Choose a CSV file")
selected_column = st.selectbox("Select column:", df.columns)
chart_type = st.radio("Chart type:", ["Line", "Bar"])
```
A) Only displays static information
B) File upload, column selection, interactive chart type selection ✓
C) Only creates one type of chart
D) No user interaction

### Q3: Problem-Solving
What key components would you include in a Streamlit app for house price prediction?
A) Only the prediction result
B) Input widgets for house features, prediction display, market insights ✓
C) Only a text box
D) No user interface needed

### Q4: Application
What Streamlit features would make a medical prediction app user-friendly for doctors?
A) Complex technical interfaces
B) Clear input labels, validation, confidence intervals, explanations ✓
C) No instructions needed
D) Hide all technical details

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
When would you choose Streamlit over traditional web frameworks?
A) For all applications always
B) For prototypes, internal tools, data science demos ✓
C) Never, traditional is always better
D) Only for very complex applications

lessons.lessonTitle:
Computer Vision

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What are the three main steps in the computer vision process?
A) Take photo, edit, save
B) Image acquisition, processing/analysis, interpretation/decision-making ✓
C) Load, display, close
D) Capture, filter, enhance

### Q2: Code Understanding
What computer vision techniques is this code applying?
```python
gray_image = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
edges = cv2.Canny(gray_image, 100, 200)
contours, _ = cv2.findContours(edges, cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL)
```
A) Only color conversion
B) Color conversion, edge detection, contour finding ✓
C) Only edge detection
D) Image enhancement only

### Q3: Problem-Solving
What computer vision approach would you design for factory quality control?
A) Manual inspection only
B) Template matching for shape, edge detection for cracks, texture analysis ✓
C) Random sampling
D) Color analysis only

### Q4: Application
Why is accuracy critical for self-driving car computer vision?
A) For better graphics
B) Safety, legal liability, public trust ✓
C) Faster processing
D) Lower costs

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
Why might computer vision fail where human vision succeeds?
A) Computers are always better
B) Humans use context, experience, and inference beyond pixel patterns ✓
C) Human vision is unreliable
D) Computer vision never fails

---

questions.prompt: What are the three main steps in the computer vision process?

feedback.short: Not quite! Deployed models need regular monitoring and retraining to maintain performance.
feedback.detailed: Real-world data changes over time (concept drift). User behavior shifts, new patterns emerge, and old patterns become obsolete. Production ML systems require continuous monitoring, periodic retraining with fresh data, and sometimes real-time updates. Model deployment is an ongoing process, not a one-time event.
feedback.socraticHint: If you trained a product recommendation model in 2020, would it still understand user preferences in 2025?

feedback.short: Not quite! Streamlit is a framework for creating complete web applications with both frontend and backend.
feedback.detailed: Streamlit simplifies full-stack development by letting you build interactive web UIs using only Python. It handles both the frontend (user interface, widgets, visualizations) and backend (data processing, ML model execution) without requiring separate HTML/CSS/JavaScript. It's designed for rapid prototyping of data applications and ML demos.
feedback.socraticHint: If Streamlit only handled backend logic, how would users interact with your ML model through a web browser?

lessons.lessonTitle:
Object Detection with YOLO Algorithm

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What does YOLO stand for and why is it called "single-shot"?
A) You Only Live Once, processes one image at a time
B) You Only Look Once, single neural network pass for detection ✓
C) Year Of Learning Objects, single year training
D) Yielding Optimal Learning Outcomes, one optimization

### Q2: Code Understanding
What does the confidence threshold control in YOLO detection?
```python
confidence = detection[5]
if confidence > 0.5:
    # Process detection
```
A) Image brightness
B) Minimum certainty required for reporting detections ✓
C) Processing speed
D) Number of objects detected

### Q3: Problem-Solving
How would YOLO help an autonomous delivery robot navigate sidewalks?
A) It wouldn't help with navigation
B) Real-time multi-object detection of pedestrians, obstacles, vehicles ✓
C) Only for taking pictures
D) Only for indoor navigation

### Q4: Application
What challenges exist for social media object detection with diverse user content?
A) No challenges exist
B) Diverse content, unusual objects, privacy concerns, accuracy requirements ✓
C) Only technical challenges
D) Users always upload perfect images

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
What drives continuous improvements in YOLO versions?
A) Marketing reasons only
B) Better architectures, training techniques, hardware optimization ✓
C) No improvements are needed
D) Competition with other companies

---

questions.prompt: What does YOLO stand for and why is it called "single-shot"?

options.text: You Only Live Once, processes one image at a time

feedback.short: Not quite\! YOLO balances both speed and accuracy through its architecture.
feedback.detailed: YOLOs single-pass architecture enables real-time detection (speed) while its grid-based prediction system with anchor boxes maintains competitive accuracy. The trade-off is carefully engineered.
feedback.socraticHint: If YOLO only cared about speed, why would it bother dividing images into grids and using multiple anchor boxes?

lessons.lessonTitle:
Deep Learning & Image Classification

### Q1: Vocabulary/Concepts
What makes deep learning particularly effective for image classification?
A) It uses more memory
B) Hierarchical feature learning and automatic pattern extraction ✓
C) It's newer than other methods
D) It has better graphics

### Q2: Code Understanding
How do convolutional and pooling layers work together in this CNN?
```python
layers.Conv2D(32, (3, 3), activation='relu'),
layers.MaxPooling2D((2, 2)),
```
A) They compete with each other
B) Conv extracts features, pooling reduces dimensionality while preserving important features ✓
C) They do the same thing
D) Pooling extracts features, conv reduces size

### Q3: Problem-Solving
What deep learning approach would you design for classifying 100 animal species from camera trap photos?
A) Use basic machine learning only
B) Transfer learning from pretrained model, data augmentation, expert validation ✓
C) Manual classification only
D) Random classification

### Q4: Application
What safety considerations are essential for medical AI image classification?
A) No safety considerations needed
B) Human oversight, confidence thresholds, regulatory approval, liability considerations ✓
C) Only speed considerations
D) Only cost considerations

### Q5: Reflection/Meta-learning
When is the "black box" nature of deep learning acceptable vs when do we need explainable AI?
A) Always acceptable
B) Acceptable for consumer apps, need explanations for medical/legal decisions ✓
C) Never acceptable
D) Only acceptable for images
